Award.AwardTitle: REU Site (Collaborative Research): Before and After a Supereruption: Magmatic Insights from the Southern Black Mountains, AZ
Award.AbstractNarration:
Supereruptions - explosive events that eject more than 1000 cubic kilometers of volcanic material - capture our imagination and compel us to consider the potential effects of one of Earth's rarest yet deadliest acts. Comprehending what led to supereruptions in the past is essential to understanding and predicting similar events in places where supereruptive activity is currently possible, including the U.S. (e.g. Yellowstone), South America, Indonesia, and New Zealand. This project will investigate an exemplary exposure of 18- to 19-million-year-old volcanic and intrusive igneous rocks in the southern Black Mountains of Arizona, where the geologic record documents magmatic evolution of the Peach Spring Tuff supereruption, which is the focus of this project. Students participating in the REU will address questions that are important to both the scientific community and the public: (1) How does supereruptive magmatism compare to typical-scale magmatism (e.g. Mount St. Helens in 1980), and how are these connected? (2) What does a supervolcano look like before it erupts? (3) What are the relationships between intrusive rocks and spatially and temporally associated volcanics? (4) How and why do large magmatic systems change through time? It will also provide a platform for testing and applying integrated field and analytical methods for tracking evolution of magma systems, including optical and scanning electron microscopy, rock and mineral analysis by X-ray fluorescence and laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, GIS, and remote sensing, tools that can also be combined to address questions at other magmatic centers.

In addition to advancing the understanding of the magmatic systems that produce supervolcanoes and thereby enhancing comprehension and forecasting of future supereruptions, this project will provide a valuable introduction to research for 30 diverse undergraduates whose opportunities may be otherwise limited. It will contribute to the scientific literacy, problem solving and communication skills and the confidence of this group of students, thereby enhancing their general education, and it will attract future earth scientists to the field, providing them with a sound foundation to begin a graduate or professional career and enduring collegial relationships with peers and faculty. This project will foster new and continuing collaborations involving participating students, leaders, and researchers at other academic institutions. It will also provide valuable mentoring experience for two early-career faculty (one female) and one outstanding female PhD student, all of whom are pursuing careers emphasizing mentoring undergraduate researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Vanderbilt-Mercyhurst University Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) project aimed to provide a unique, challenging, multi-faceted experience and yield important geoscience results.  Aims were to:

  • Investigate the geological history of a 17 to 20 million-year-old volcanic center whose eruption products spanned southeastern California, northwestern Arizona, and southernmost Nevada;
  • Understand processes that led to and followed the 18.8 million-year-old supereruption of Peach Springs Tuff, which blanketed an area of more than 30,000 square km with 1,000 cubic km of ash

While providing students with:

  • Enhanced oral and written communications skills;
  • Increased geoscience knowledge and experience with challenging research problems, employing field observations, advanced analytical techniques, and scientific reasoning;
  • Improved confidence as geoscientists and motivation for science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM);
  • Collaborative experience and collegial relationships, enhancing motivation and ability to pursue STEM (or other) careers

Each year (2013-14 through 2015-16), 10 students were selected for the program.  We sought students who were highly motivated but whose home institutions provided limited opportunities for comparable research, and we focused on smaller colleges and universities in the regions of the collaborating universities (Tennessee, Kentucky, western Pennsylvania-New York).  Nineteen of the 29 students who completed the program came from schools with limited research undergraduate opportunities. 

Participants spent four weeks during January and May sessions camping in the desert wilderness field area (AZ-CA-NV).  The January session was devoted to training and May to field research.  Field work was followed by 5 weeks of lab research and report preparation at Vanderbilt (seven students, microscope work and chemical analyses) or Mercyhurst (three students, using remote sensing techniques [multispectral satellite data for the field area]).  All participants collaborated in a general way as a group, both scientifically and for life in the field under difficult conditions (rugged mountain terrane; cold and sometimes rainy or snowy in January, hot in May).  They broke down into groups of two to four to focus on related sets of problems, and each student selected an individual research project that he or she turned into a published abstract and a poster for the annual meeting of the Geological Society of America.

The three-year team effort compiled a large data base for volcanism in the field area, including reconnaissance mapping of a large area (using remote sensing with local field explorations) and detailed maps of small areas and geochemical analyses of hundreds of rocks, minerals, and volcanic glasses.  They used these data to investigate relations and temporal trends among volcanic units and to model magmatic processes and pressure-temperature conditions prior to eruptions. 

The project achieved its goals of bringing into clearer focus the history of a volcanic center that produced a supereruption and adding critical detail to understanding of processes during that eruption.  Findings include:

  • The PST eruption was preceded by 0.5 million years of eruptions from nearby volcanoes.  Most eruptions produced moderate-sized lava flows of intermediate composition (60-70% silica).  A single large explosive eruption produced the Cook Canyon Tuff (CCT, 19.0 million years old), with a composition similar to the lavas; several smaller explosive eruptions before and after CCT yielded silicic ash fall deposits (70-75 % silica).  Shortly before the PST eruption, hot, low-volume mafic lavas (50-55% silica) erupted.
  • Exposures of distinctive tuff (65-70% silica, crystal-rich) that locally overlie typical PST (76% silica, crystal-poor) reveal final stages of the eruption and the nature of the base of the magma chamber.  This deep magma experienced extreme heating and ascended into and mingled with overlying silicic magma during the eruption.  The PST chamber prior to eruption was a thick, stratified but continuous magma body, in contrast to multiple discrete bodies that are interpreted to have fed other supereruptions
  • Inclusions of quenched mafic magma were entrained within the erupted PST; these inclusions may reflect a source of heat that triggered the eruption.
  • Post-PST, eruption rate fell dramatically.  For the next two million years, small eruptions alternating between lava and explosive were mostly silicic.  Mafic eruptions were conspicuously absent.

The REU participants presented 38 posters with accompanying abstracts at national meetings.  One student carried her research into her subsequent Master’s thesis, submitting it to a major international journal, and another student intends to submit his research for publication soon.  Several more papers are anticipated. 

The leaders of the REU have presented 10 papers at meetings, including scientific syntheses and summaries of pedagogical insights from the REU.  They are preparing a paper on the latter topic for a science education journal.

All 29 REU participants have graduated with a geoscience bachelor’s degree, and 27 are continuing on STEM career paths.  Five went directly into the workforce (education, environmental consulting, state conservation).  The remaining 22 are currently in or have completed graduate programs.  Nineteen initially enrolled in Master’s and three in PhD programs; seven of the MS students continued on, or will soon continue, to PhD programs.
